The fool says in his heart, “There is no God.”
They are corrupt. They commit horrible evil.
There is no one who does good.
53.2:
God looks down from heaven on all the children of Adam
    to see if there is anyone who understands,
    anyone who seeks God.
53.3:
Every single one has turned back.
Altogether they have become rotten.
There is no one who does good.
There is not even one.
53.4:
Don’t they know, all those evildoers,
    who devour my people as if they were eating bread?
They do not call on God.
53.5:
There they are, terrified, where there was nothing to fear.
For God scattered the bones of those who camped against you.
You put them to shame, because God despised them.
53.6:
Who will provide salvation for Israel from Zion?
When God restores his people, let Jacob rejoice and Israel be glad!

54.1:
God, save me by your name.
By your power judge me justly.
54.2:
God, hear my prayer.
Turn your ear to the words of my mouth.
54.3:
For strangers have risen up against me.
Ruthless men seek my life. Interlude
They pay no attention to God.
54.4:
Indeed, God is my helper.
The Lord is the one who preserves my life.
54.5:
Let evil return on those who oppress me.
In your faithfulness destroy them.
54.6:
I will sacrifice willingly to you.
I will praise your name, O Lord, because it is good.
54.7:
Surely, from all my distress he has delivered me.
My eyes have looked down on my enemies.

55.1:
Turn your ear to my prayer, O God.
Do not hide from my plea for mercy.
55.2:
Pay attention to me and answer me.
I am troubled in my thoughts and I groan
55.3:
because of talk from the enemy,
    because of oppression from the wicked,
    because they dump evil on me,
    and in anger they hold a grudge against me.
55.4:
My heart is in anguish within me.
The terrors of death fall on me.
55.5:
Fear and trembling come over me.
Horror covers me.
55.6:
So I say, “I wish I had wings like a dove!
I would fly away and find a place to rest.
55.7:
Yes, I would flee far away. Interlude
I would stay in the wilderness.
55.8:
I would hurry to find shelter,
    far from the violent wind, far from the storm.”
55.9:
Swallow them up, O Lord.
Confuse their speech,
for I see violence and contention in the city.
55.10:
Day and night they sneak around on its walls.
Evil and trouble are in the city.
55.11:
Destruction lurks within it.
Treachery and deceit never leave its streets.
55.12:
For it is not an enemy who insults me—
I could bear that.
It is not someone who hated me who rises up against me—
I could hide from him.
55.13:
But it is you, a man who served with me,
    my colleague and my associate,
55.14:
with whom I shared pleasant discussions
    as we walked with the excited crowd at God’s house.
55.15:
Let deadly destruction come on them.
Let them go down to the grave alive,
because evil is at home in their hearts.
55.16:
As for me, I call to God,
and the Lord saves me.
55.17:
Evening, morning, and noon I cry out and I sigh,
and he hears my voice.
55.18:
In peace he redeems my life from the assault against me,
    even when many are against me.
55.19:
God will hear, and he will punish them— Interlude
yes, he is seated on his throne from eternity!
—because they never change, and they do not fear God.
55.20:
The traitor reaches out his hand against those at peace with him.
He breaks his agreement.
55.21:
His flattery is as smooth as butter,
yet war is in his heart.
His words are more soothing than oil,
yet they are drawn daggers.
55.22:
Place your burden on the Lord,
and he will support you.
He will never allow the righteous to fall.
55.23:
But you, O God, will bring them down into the pit of destruction.
Bloody and deceitful men will not live half their days.
But as for me, I will trust in you.

56.1:
For the choir director. “A Dove on Distant Oaks.”
By David. A miktam.
When the Philistines had seized him in Gath.
56.2:
Be merciful to me, O God, for a man pants as he pursues me.
All day long an attacker presses against me.
56.3:
Those who spy on me pant as they pursue me all day long.
Yes, many are attacking me boldly.
56.4: On the day when I am afraid, I will trust in you.
56.5:
In God I praise his word.
In God I trust. I will not fear.
What can flesh do to me?
56.6:
All day long they hurt my cause.
All their thoughts against me are evil.
56.7:
They gather together. They hide.
They try to trip me by grabbing my heels
    while they wait to take my life.
56.8:
Because of their wickedness do not let them escape.
In your anger bring down the peoples, O God.
56.9:
You keep a record of my tossing and turning.
Keep my tears in your bottle.
Aren’t they all listed in your book?
56.10:
Then my enemies will turn back on the day when I call.
This is how I will know that God is for me.
56.11:
In God I praise a word.
In the Lord I praise a word.
56.12:
In God I trust. I will not be afraid.
What can man do to me?
56.13:
My vows to you are binding, O God.
I will complete my thank offerings to you,
56.14:
because you have delivered my life from death.
Have you not delivered my feet from stumbling
    so I can walk before God in the light of life?

57.1:
For the choir director. “Do Not Destroy.” By David. A miktam.
When he fled from Saul. In the cave.
57.2:
Have mercy on me, O God,
have mercy on me,
because my soul has taken refuge in you.
In the shadow of your wings I will take refuge
    until destruction has passed by.
57.3:
I call to God Most High,
to God, who completes his plans for me.
57.4:
He will send from heaven, and he will save me. Interlude
He puts to shame the one who pants as he pursues me.
God will send his mercy and his faithfulness.
57.5:
My life is spent among lions.
I lie down among ferocious men,
whose teeth are spears and arrows,
whose tongue is a sharp sword.
57.6:
Be exalted above the heavens, O God.
May your glory be over all the earth.
57.7:
They spread a net for my steps.
My soul was bowed down.
They dug a pit in front of me. Interlude
They have fallen into it.
57.8:
My heart is steadfast, O God.
My heart is steadfast.
I will sing and I will make music.
57.9:
Awake, my soul!
Awake, harp and lyre!
I will awaken the dawn.
57.10:
I will give thanks to you among the peoples, O Lord.
I will make music to you among the nations,
57.11:
because your great mercy reaches above the heavens,
and your faithfulness to the skies.
57.12:
Be exalted above the heavens, O God.
Let your glory be over all the earth.

58.1: For the choir director. “Do Not Destroy.” By David. A miktam.
58.2:
Do you “gods” really speak righteously?
Do you sons of Adam judge rightly?
58.3:
No, in your heart you commit injustices.
On the earth your hands distribute violence.
58.4:
The wicked go off course already from the womb.
From the belly they go astray. They speak lies.
58.5:
Their venom is like the venom of a snake,
like a deaf cobra that has stopped its ears,
58.6:
that will not listen to the sound of the charmers,
however skillful the spellbinder may be.
58.7:
O God, break their teeth in their mouths.
Tear out the fangs of the young lions, Lord!
58.8:
Let them vanish like water that flows away.
When he draws his bow, let his arrows be cut off.
58.9:
As a slug melts away as it crawls along, so let him disappear.
Like a stillborn child may they not see the sun.
58.10:
Before your pots can feel the heat of the thorns—
whether the thorns are green or dry—they will be swept away.
58.11:
The righteous one will be glad when he sees vengeance.
He will bathe his feet in the blood of the wicked.
58.12:
Then people will say, “Surely there is fruit for the righteous.
Surely there is a God judging on the earth.”

59.1:
Deliver me from my enemies, my God.
You set me high above those who rise up against me.
59.2:
Deliver me from evildoers.
Save me from bloodthirsty men.
59.3:
Yes, look how they lie in ambush to take my life!
Strong men gather against me,
but it is not because I have rebelled,
not because I have sinned, O Lord.
59.4:
I am not guilty,
yet they run to take up their positions against me.
Rise up to meet me and see!
59.5:
You, O Lord, God of Armies, the God of Israel,
wake up and confront all the nations. Interlude
Do not show mercy to all the wicked traitors.
59.6:
They return at evening. They growl like dogs.
They prowl around the city.
59.7:
Look, they gush from their mouths.
Their lips are swords,
so they say, “Who hears?”
59.8:
But you laugh at them, Lord.
You scoff at all those nations.
59.9:
O my Strength, I watch for you,
because God is my high fortress.
59.10:
My merciful God will go ahead of me.
God will make me look down on those who slander me.
59.11:
Do not kill them, or my people may forget.
In your might make them wander about.
Bring them down, O Lord, our shield.
59.12:
The sin of their mouth is the words of their lips,
so let them be caught in their pride,
because of the curses and lies they proclaim.
59.13:
Consume them in wrath.
Consume them till they are no more.
Then they will know to the ends of the earth Interlude
    that God rules over Jacob.
59.14:
They return at evening. They growl like dogs.
They prowl around the city.
59.15:
They wander about for food.
If not satisfied, they howl.
59.16:
But I will sing about your strength.
In the morning I will shout about your mercy,
because you are a high fortress for me,
a refuge in the day of my distress.
59.17:
O my Strength, to you I make music,
because God is my high fortress, my merciful God.

60.1:
For the choir director. “The Lily of Testimony.” A miktam by David.
For teaching. When he waged war against Aram Naharaim and against Aram Zobah, and Joab returned and struck down twelve thousand men of Edom in the Valley of Salt.
60.2:
God, you have rejected us.
You have broken us down.
You have been angry. Return to us!
60.3:
You have shaken the earth. You have torn it open.
Heal its fractures, for it is about to collapse.
60.4:
You have made your people suffer hardship.
You gave us wine to drink that makes us stagger.
60.5:
You have set up a signal flag for those who fear you, Interlude
    to be raised up against the bow.
60.6:
Save us with your right hand and answer us,
so that those you love may be delivered.
60.7:
God has spoken in his holiness:
“I will triumph. I will distribute Shechem,
and I will measure off the Valley of Succoth.
60.8:
Gilead is mine, and Manasseh is mine.
Ephraim is my helmet. Judah is my scepter.
60.9:
Moab is my washbasin. On Edom I toss my sandal.
I shout aloud over Philistia.”
60.10:
Who will bring me into the fortified city?
Who will lead me to Edom?
60.11:
God, is it not you, who have rejected us?
God, is it not you, who no longer go out with our armies?
60.12:
Give us help against the foe,
for human help is worthless.
60.13:
In God we will do mighty deeds.
He is the one who will trample our foes.

61.1: For the choir director. On a stringed instrument. By David.
61.2:
Hear my cry, O God.
Pay attention to my prayer.
61.3:
From the end of the earth I call to you
    when my heart is overwhelmed.
Lead me up onto the rock that is higher than I.
61.4:
For you have been a refuge for me,
a tower of strength in the face of the enemy.
61.5:
I want to keep living in your tent forever. Interlude
I will take refuge under the cover of your wings.
61.6:
For you, God, have heard my vows.
You have given me the heritage of those who fear your name.
61.7:
Add days to the days of the king.
His years will last through all generations.
61.8:
Let him be seated in God’s presence forever.
Appoint your mercy and truth to protect him.
61.9:
Then will I make music to your name forever,
    to fulfill my vows day after day.

62.1: For the choir director. According to Jeduthun. A psalm by David.
62.2:
My soul rests quietly in God alone.
My salvation is from him.
62.3:
He alone is my rock and my salvation, my fortress.
I will not be disturbed.
62.4:
How long will you threaten a man?
Do all of you want to murder him,
    like a leaning wall, like a fence to be pushed down?
62.5:
Yes, they plan to push him down from his lofty place.
They are delighted with deceit.
With their mouths they bless,
but inside they curse. Interlude
62.6:
My soul, rest quietly in God alone,
for my hope comes from him.
62.7:
He alone is my rock and my salvation, my fortress.
I will not be disturbed.
62.8:
My salvation and my honor depend on God, my strong rock.
My refuge is in God.
62.9:
Trust in him at all times, you people.
Pour out your hearts before him. Interlude
God is a refuge for us.
62.10:
Yes, the sons of Adam are only a breath.
The sons of man are a delusion.
On a scale they weigh nothing.
They are nothing but air.
62.11:
Do not trust in extortion.
Do not put empty confidence in stolen goods.
If your wealth grows, do not set your heart on it.
62.12:
One thing God has spoken,
two things that I have heard:
    that God has strength
62.13:
and that you, Lord, have mercy.
Surely you will repay each person
    according to what he has done.

63.1: A psalm by David. When he was in the wilderness of Judah.
63.2:
God, you are my God. Eagerly I seek you.
My soul thirsts for you. My flesh longs for you,
    in a dry and dreary land without water.
63.3:
Yes, in the sanctuary I have watched you
    to see your power and your glory.
63.4:
Because your mercy is better than life,
    my lips will worship you.
63.5:
Yes, I will bless you as long as I live.
In your name I will lift up my hands.
63.6:
My soul will be satisfied with rich food.
My mouth will praise you with lips filled with songs.
63.7:
Whenever I remember you on my bed,
throughout the watches of the night I meditate on you.
63.8:
Because you are a help for me,
I sing for joy under the shade of your wings.
63.9:
My soul clings to you.
Your right hand upholds me.
63.10:
But those who seek my life will go to destruction.
They will go into the depths of the earth.
63.11:
They will be given over to the power of the sword.
They will become food for foxes.
63.12:
But the king will rejoice in God.
All who swear by him will praise him,
but the mouths of those speaking lies will be shut.

64.1:
Hear my voice, O God, when I complain.
Protect my life from the terror caused by the enemy.
64.2:
Hide me from the conspiracy of the wicked,
from the noisy mob of evildoers.
64.3:
They sharpen their tongues like a sword.
They shoot poison words like arrows.
64.4:
They shoot at the innocent from hiding places.
Suddenly they shoot at him. They have no fear.
64.5:
They strengthen each other in an evil plot.
They discuss where to hide snares.
They say, “Who will see them?”
64.6:
They plot evil deeds and they say,
“We have come up with a perfect plot!”
The mind and heart of man are devious!
64.7:
But God will shoot them.
Suddenly they are wounded with an arrow.
64.8:
Their own tongues cause their downfall.
Everyone who sees them will shake his head.
64.9:
Then all people will be afraid.
They will proclaim the work of God.
They will consider what he has done.
64.10:
Let the righteous rejoice in the Lord
and take refuge in him.
Let all the upright in heart be confident!

65.1:
Praise waits for you, O God, in Zion.
To you vows will be fulfilled.
65.2: You who hear prayer, to you all mortals will come.
65.3:
The record of my guilt overpowered me.
You atone for our rebellious acts.
65.4:
How blessed is the one you choose and bring near!
He will dwell in your courtyards.
We will be satisfied by the goodness of your house,
by the holiness of your temple.
65.5:
In righteousness you answer us with awesome deeds,
    O God who saves us.
He is trusted by all the farthest ends of the earth and the sea.
65.6:
He establishes the mountains by his power.
He has wrapped himself with strength.
65.7:
He stills the roaring of the seas,
the roaring of their waves,
and the turmoil of the peoples.
65.8:
Those living at the ends of the earth fear your signs.
From sunrise to sunset you let them shout for joy.
65.9:
You visit the earth and water it.
You make it very rich.
God’s stream is filled with water.
You provide grain for them, just as you planned.
65.10:
You drench the land’s furrows. You flatten its plowed ground.
You soften it with showers. You bless its crops.
65.11:
You crown the year with your goodness.
The tracks made by your carts overflow with riches.
65.12:
The pastures of the wilderness drip.
The hills are wrapped with joy.
65.13:
The meadows are clothed with flocks.
The valleys are dressed with grain.
They shout for joy. Yes! They sing.

66.1: Shout praise to God, all the earth!
66.2:
Make music to the glory of his name!
Make his praise glorious!
66.3:
Say to God, “How awesome are your deeds!”
Because of your great power your enemies must cower before you.
66.4:
All the earth bows down to you.
They make music to you.
They make music to your name. Interlude
66.5:
Come and see the works of God.
How awesome his deeds for all people!
66.6:
He turned the sea into dry land.
They crossed through the river on foot.
Let us rejoice in him there.
66.7:
He rules by his power forever.
His eyes watch the nations. Interlude
Do not let the rebellious rise up against him.
66.8:
Bless our God, you peoples.
Let the sound of his praise be heard.
66.9:
He is the one who has preserved our lives.
He did not let our feet slip.
66.10:
Indeed, you tested us, God.
You refined us as silver is refined.
66.11:
You led us into a trap.
You laid a burden on our backs.
66.12:
You let men ride over our heads.
We went through fire and through water,
but you brought us out to a well-watered place.
66.13:
I will come to your house with whole burnt offerings.
I will fulfill my vows to you,
66.14:
which my lips uttered,
    which my mouth spoke during my trouble.
66.15:
I will offer fat animals to you as whole burnt offerings,
    along with the smoke from rams. Interlude
I will offer cattle with goats.
66.16:
Come, listen, all you who fear God,
and let me tell what he has done to save my life.
66.17:
To him I cried out with my mouth.
High praise was on my tongue.
66.18:
If I had contemplated evil in my heart,
the Lord would not have listened,
66.19:
but God has surely listened.
He has paid attention to the sound of my prayer.
66.20:
Blessed be God, who has not turned aside my prayer
or turned aside his mercy from me!

67.1:
May God be gracious to us and bless us. Interlude
May his face shine on us—
67.2:
so that your way may be known on earth,
your salvation among all nations.
67.3:
May the peoples praise you, O God.
May the peoples praise you—all of them.
67.4:
May the countries be glad and sing for joy,
because you rule the peoples with fairness, Interlude
and you guide the countries of the earth.
67.5:
May the peoples praise you, O God.
May the peoples praise you—all of them.
67.6:
The earth will yield its harvest.
God, our God, will bless us.
67.7:
God will bless us,
and all the ends of the earth will fear him.

68.1:
May God arise. May his enemies scatter.
May those who hate him flee from his presence.
68.2:
As smoke is blown away, may you blow them away.
As wax melts before the fire, may the wicked perish before God.
68.3:
But the righteous rejoice and celebrate in the presence of God.
They will be happy and joyful.
68.4:
Sing to God. Make music to his name.
Lift up a song to him who rides through the deserts.
His name is the Lord. Celebrate before him.
68.5:
In his holy dwelling, God is a father for the fatherless
and a judge who defends widows.
68.6:
God causes the lonely to dwell together as a household.
He leads out the prisoners with music,
but the rebellious dwell in a scorched land.
68.7:
God, when you went out in front of your people,
when you marched through the wasteland, Interlude
68.8:
the earth shook.
Yes, the heavens poured down rain,
    before God, this one from Sinai,
    before God, the God of Israel.
68.9:
You dispersed plentiful showers, O God.
You strengthened your inheritance when it was weary.
68.10:
Your people settled in it.
In your goodness you provided for the oppressed, O God.
68.11:
The Lord provided the message.
The women who proclaimed it were a great army:
68.12:
“Kings with armies flee—they flee!”
The woman who stays home shares in the plunder.
68.13:
Even while you lie among the campfires,
the wings of a dove are sheathed with silver,
and its feathers with yellow gold.
68.14:
When the Almighty scattered the kings there,
it snowed on Zalmon.
68.15:
The mountain of Bashan is a mountain of God.
The mountain of Bashan is a mountain with many peaks.
68.16:
O mountains with many peaks, why do you look jealously
    at the mountain God desires for his home?
Indeed, the Lord will dwell there forever.
68.17:
The chariots of God are twice ten thousand,
thousands upon thousands.
Among them the Lord has come from Sinai into his sanctuary.
68.18:
You ascended on high. You led captivity captive.
You received gifts among men,
so that even among the rebellious the Lord God might dwell.
68.19:
Blessed be the Lord.
Day by day he bears our burdens.
He is the God who saves us. Interlude
68.20:
Our God is a God who saves.
From God the Lord comes escape from death.
68.21:
Surely God will crush the heads of his enemies,
the scalps of those who walk around in their guilt.
68.22:
The Lord says, “I will bring them from Bashan.
I will bring them from the depths of the sea,
68.23:
so that you may stomp your foot in blood.
The tongues of your dogs get their share of the enemies’ blood.”
68.24:
They see your processions, O God,
the processions of my God, my King, into the sanctuary.
68.25:
The singers lead the way.
After them come the musicians.
In the middle are virgins playing hand drums.
68.26:
In the assemblies bless God, the Lord,
    who is the Fountain of Israel.
68.27:
There is little Benjamin, leading them.
The officers of Judah are their noisy crowd.
There are the officers of Zebulun and the officers of Naphtali.
68.28:
Your God commands your strength.
Show strength, O God, as you have done for us before.
68.29: Because of your temple at Jerusalem kings will bring tribute to you.
68.30:
Threaten the beast among the reeds,
the herd of strong bulls among the calves (that is, the peoples),
    until they submit with bars of silver.
He scatters the peoples who delight in battles.
68.31:
Envoys will come from Egypt.
Cush will run to stretch out its hands to God.
68.32:
Sing to God, you kingdoms of the earth. Interlude
Make music to the Lord,
68.33:
to him who rides in the highest heavens,
    in the ancient heavens.
Yes, he sends out his voice, his mighty voice.
68.34:
Proclaim God’s strength.
His majesty is over Israel,
and his power is in the skies.
68.35:
You are awesome, O God, from your sanctuary.
The God of Israel, he is the one
    who gives power and strength to the people.
Blessed be God!

69.1: For the choir director. According to “Lilies.” By David.
69.2: Save me, O God, for the waters have come up to my neck.
69.3:
I sink into the deep mud, where there is no place to stand.
I have entered deep waters, and the rapids rush over me.
69.4:
I am worn out from my crying. My throat is sore.
My eyes are blurry, as I wait for my God.
69.5:
Those who hate me without reason outnumber the hairs on my head.
Those who want to destroy me, my lying enemies, are strong.
I must repay things I did not steal.
69.6:
God, you know my folly,
and my guilt is not hidden from you.
69.7:
May those who place their confidence in you
    not be put to shame because of me,
    O Lord, the Lord of Armies.
May those who seek you not be disgraced because of me,
    O God of Israel.
69.8:
It is for your sake that I bear scorn.
Shame covers my face.
69.9:
I have become a stranger to my brothers,
a foreigner to my mother’s sons.
69.10:
Yes, zeal for your house consumes me.
The scorn of those who scorn you falls on me.
69.11:
I wept as I fasted,
but this only brought insults to me.
69.12:
When I wore sackcloth as my clothing,
I was a joke to them.
69.13:
Those who sit in the gatehouse gossip about me,
and the songs of the drunks are about me.
69.14:
But I direct my prayer to you, O Lord, for a time of favor.
God, in the greatness of your mercy,
    answer me with the certainty of salvation from you.
69.15:
Rescue me from the mud, so I do not sink.
Let me escape from those who hate me and from the deep waters.
69.16:
Do not let the rapids rush over me.
Do not let the deep swallow me up.
Do not let the pit close its mouth over me.
69.17:
Answer me, Lord, for your mercy is good.
According to your great compassion, turn to me.
69.18:
Do not hide your face from your servant.
Because I am in distress, hurry, answer me.
69.19:
Come near. Redeem my soul.
Ransom me because of my enemies.
69.20:
You know my disgrace, my shame, and my confusion.
All my foes are in front of you.
69.21:
Disgrace has broken my heart, and I am helpless.
I waited for sympathy, but there was none.
I waited for comforters, but I did not find any.
69.22:
Instead they put bitter poison in my food.
For my thirst they gave me sour wine to drink.
69.23:
May the table set before them become a snare.
May it be a trap to them and their allies.
69.24:
May their eyes be darkened so they cannot see.
Make their legs always tremble.
69.25:
Pour out your wrath on them.
Let the heat of your anger catch up with them.
69.26:
May their camp be desolate.
May there be no one dwelling in their tents.
69.27:
For they pursue those you have disciplined, O God,
and they talk about the pain of those you wound.
69.28:
Add guilt to their guilt.
Do not let them enter into your righteousness.
69.29:
May they be erased from the book of life.
May they not be listed among the righteous.
69.30:
But I am afflicted and in pain.
O God, may salvation from you set me on high.
69.31:
I will praise God’s name in song.
I will proclaim his greatness with thanksgiving.
69.32:
For the Lord this is better than an ox,
than a bull that has horns and hoofs.
69.33:
The poor will see and be glad.
You who seek God, may your hearts live!
69.34:
For the Lord listens to the needy,
and he does not despise the captives who belong to him.
69.35:
Let heaven and earth praise him,
the seas and all that move in them,
69.37:
Then the descendants of his servants will inherit it,
and those who love his name will dwell in it.

70.1:
Hurry, God! Rescue me!
Lord, hurry to help me!
70.2:
May those who seek my life be put to shame and disgrace.
May all who desire to harm me be turned back and disgraced.
70.3:
May those who say, “Aha! We got you!” be dismayed,
because they have been put to shame.
70.4:
But may all who seek you rejoice and be glad in you.
May those who love your salvation always say, “Let God be exalted!”
70.5:
Yet I am oppressed and poor.
God, hurry to me. You are my help and my deliverer.
O Lord, do not delay.

71.1:
In you, Lord, I have taken refuge.
May I not be put to shame forever.
71.2:
In your righteousness rescue me and deliver me.
Turn your ear to me and save me.
71.3:
Be my rock and my refuge to which I can always go.
You give the command to save me,
because you are my high ridge and my stronghold.
71.4:
My God, deliver me from the hand of the wicked,
from the grasp of the unjust and the ruthless.
71.5:
For you have been my hope, Lord God,
my confidence since my youth.
71.6:
I have depended on you since I was in the womb.
You separated me from my mother’s body.
My praise to you is continuous.
71.7:
I am like an evil omen to many,
but you are my strong refuge.
71.8:
My mouth is filled with praise for you
and with your splendor all day long.
71.9:
Do not throw me away in old age.
As my strength fails, do not forsake me.
71.10:
For my enemies speak against me,
and those who seek my life conspire together.
71.11:
They say, “God has forsaken him.
Pursue him and seize him,
because there is no one to rescue him.”
71.12:
God, do not be far from me.
My God, hurry to help me.
71.13:
Let them be ashamed.
Let my murderous accusers be consumed.
Let those who seek to harm me be covered
    with shame and disgrace.
71.14:
But as for me, I will always keep hoping.
I will keep adding to my praise for you.
71.15:
My mouth will tell about your righteousness,
about your salvation all day long,
although I do not know how to tell all about it.
71.16:
I will come and tell about your mighty deeds, Lord God.
I will commemorate your righteousness, yours alone.
71.17:
God, you have taught me since my youth,
and even now I still declare your marvelous deeds.
71.18:
Even when I am old and gray, O God, do not forsake me,
till I declare the strength of your arm to the next generation,
your power to all who are to come.
71.19:
Your righteousness, God, reaches to the heights.
You have done great things.
God, who is like you,
71.20:
you who have made us see many troubles and disasters?
You will give us life again.
From the depths of the earth you will bring me up again.
71.21: You will increase my greatness and comfort me once again.
71.22:
Yes, I will praise you, my God, for your faithfulness.
I will praise you with an instrument, with the harp.
I will make music to you with the lyre, O Holy One of Israel.
71.23:
My lips will shout with joy when I make music to you.
Even my soul, which you have redeemed, will shout.
71.24:
Indeed, my tongue will tell of your righteousness all day long.
How ashamed, how disgraced they are—
    those who are trying to harm me.

72.2:
God, give your authority to judge to the King.
Give your righteousness to the Son of the King.
72.3:
He will judge your people with righteousness.
He will judge your afflicted ones with justice.
72.4:
The mountains will deliver peace to the people.
The hills will produce righteousness.
72.5:
He will obtain justice for the afflicted among the people.
He will save the children of the poor,
but he will crush the oppressor.
72.6:
They will fear you as long as the sun remains,
and as long as the moon endures, through all generations.
72.7:
He will come down like rain on a mown field,
like showers, like a downpour on the earth.
72.8:
In his days the righteous will flourish,
and peace will be plentiful till the moon is no more.
72.9:
He will rule from sea to sea
and from the River to the ends of the earth.
72.10:
Those who dwell in the desert will bow before him,
and his enemies will lick the dust.
72.11:
The kings of Tarshish and of the sea coasts will bring tribute.
The kings of Sheba and Seba will offer him gifts.
72.12:
All kings will bow down to him.
All nations will serve him.
72.13:
He will certainly deliver the poor person who cries out,
as well as the afflicted, and the one who has no helper.
72.14:
He will take pity on the weak and the poor.
He will save the lives of the poor.
72.15:
From oppression and violence he will redeem their lives,
because their blood is precious in his sight.
72.16:
May the King live!
May gold from Sheba be offered to him.
May people always pray for him.
May they bless him all day long.
72.17:
Let there be an abundance of grain in the land.
Let it wave on the top of the mountains.
Let its fruit trees be like the cedars of Lebanon.
Let people from the city flourish like the grass of the land.
72.18:
May his name endure forever.
May his name flourish as long as the sun.
They will be blessed through him.
All nations will call him blessed.
72.19:
Blessed be the Lord God, the God of Israel,
    who alone does marvelous deeds.
72.20:
Blessed be his glorious name forever.
May the whole earth be filled with his glory.
Amen and Amen.
72.21: This ends the prayers of David son of Jesse.

73.2: Surely God is good to Israel, to the pure in heart.
73.3:
But as for me, my feet almost slipped out from under me.
I almost lost my footing.
73.4: I even envied the arrogant when I observed the peace of the wicked.
73.5:
For there are no struggles at their death.
Their bodies are sturdy.
73.6:
They do not have the trouble common to people.
They are not plagued along with the rest of mankind.
73.7:
Therefore pride is their necklace.
They wear violence like clothing.
73.8:
Their eyes bulge out of their fat.
The schemes of their hearts step over boundaries.
73.9:
They mock. They speak maliciously.
From a high perch they threaten oppression.
73.10:
They set their mouths against the heavens.
Their tongues strut around on earth.
73.11:
Therefore God’s people turn to them,
and they drink it all in.
73.12:
They say, “How can God know?
Does the Most High have knowledge?”
73.13:
See, this is what the wicked are like—
secure forever, they increase in strength.
73.14:
Have I really kept my heart pure for nothing?
Have I kept my hands clean in vain?
73.15:
I have been plagued all day.
My punishment comes every morning.
73.16:
If I had said, “I will speak like this,”
I would certainly have betrayed the circle of your children.
73.17: When I tried to understand this, it was very troubling to me,
73.18:
until I went to the sanctuary of God.
Then I understood their end.
73.19:
Surely you place them on slippery places.
You cause them to fall into destruction.
73.20:
How quickly they come to ruin,
completely destroyed by terrors!
73.21:
They are like a dream when someone wakes up.
So when you arise, O Lord,
you will despise them like an illusion.
73.22:
Yes, my heart was bitter,
and I was torn up inside.
73.23:
I was unthinking and ignorant.
I was a dumb animal before you.
73.24:
Yet I am always with you.
You hold me by my right hand.
73.25:
With your guidance you lead me,
and afterward, you will take me to glory.
73.26:
Who else is there for me in heaven?
And besides you, I desire no one else on earth.
73.27:
My flesh and my heart fail,
but God is the rock of my heart and my portion forever.
73.28:
No doubt about it!
Those who are far from you will perish.
You destroy all who commit adultery against you.
73.29:
As for me, God’s nearness is good for me.
I have made the Lord God my refuge,
so that I can tell about all your works.

74.2:
Why do you stay angry to the end, O God?
Why does your anger smoke against the flock in your pasture?
74.3:
Remember your community that you purchased long ago,
the tribe that you redeemed to be your possession.
Remember Mount Zion where you dwell.
74.4:
March toward the perpetual ruins.
March against all the evil done by the enemy in the sanctuary.
74.5:
Your foes roared in the middle of your appointed place.
They set up their battle standards as signs.
74.6: They looked like men swinging axes in a thicket of trees.
74.7:
Yes, they even chopped up all the carved paneling
    with their hatchets and hammers.
74.8:
They delivered your sanctuary to the fire.
They defiled the dwelling place for your Name
    by throwing it to the ground.
74.9:
They said in their hearts, “We will crush them completely!”
They burned all the appointed places of God in the land.
74.10:
We do not see any signs to guide us.
There is no longer a prophet,
and none of us knows how long this will go on.
74.11:
How long will the foe scoff, O God?
Will the enemy insult your name forever?
74.12:
Why do you hold back your hand, even your right hand?
Take it out of your pocket and finish them off!
74.13:
But you, O God, are my king from long ago,
the one who works salvation right here on earth.
74.14:
It was you who shattered the sea by your power.
You broke the heads of the great sea monsters.
74.15:
It was you who crushed the heads of Leviathan.
You gave him as food to the people who live in the desert.
74.16:
It was you who opened up a spring and a seasonal stream.
You dried up the rivers that flow year-round.
74.17:
The day belongs to you, and the night is also yours.
You set the moon and sun in place.
74.18:
It was you who laid out all the boundaries of the earth.
Summer and winter—you shaped them.
74.19:
Remember this—the enemy scoffs, Lord,
and a foolish people has insulted your name.
74.20:
Do not surrender the life of your turtledove to a wild animal.
Do not forget the life of your afflicted ones forever.
74.21:
Pay attention to the covenant,
because dens of violence fill the dark places in the land.
74.22:
Do not let the oppressed turn back in disgrace.
Let the poor and needy praise your name.
74.23:
Rise up, O God, and prosecute your case.
Remember how the fools mocked you all day long.
74.24:
Do not forget the sound of your foes,
the uproar of those who rise against you, which goes up continually.

75.1:
We give thanks to you, O God, we give thanks.
Your wonderful deeds reveal that your name is near.
75.2:
Yes, I choose the appointed time.
I am the one who judges rightly.
75.3:
The earth and all its inhabitants are shaking.
I am the one who holds its pillars firm. Interlude
75.4:
I say to the boasters, “Do not boast,”
and to the wicked, “Do not raise a horn.
75.5:
Do not raise your horns to the heights.
Do not speak insolently with an outstretched neck.”
75.6:
Indeed, power to promote someone does not come
    from the east or from the west or from the wilderness.
75.7:
No, it is God who makes the decision.
He brings down one. He raises up another.
75.8:
Indeed, a cup is in the hand of the Lord.
The wine foams. It is fully mixed.
He pours this out.
Yes, they drain its dregs.
All the wicked of the earth drink.
75.9:
As for me, I will proclaim this forever.
I will make music for the God of Jacob.
75.10:
I will cut off all the horns of the wicked.
The horns of the righteous will be lifted up.

76.1: God is known in Judah. In Israel his name is great.
76.2: His shelter is in Salem. His dwelling place is in Zion.
76.3:
There he broke the flaming arrows, Interlude
the shield and the sword, and the weapons for battle.
76.4: You shine brightly as the Mighty One from the mountains full of prey.
76.5:
The strong-hearted are plundered.
They have fallen into their final sleep.
Not one of the strong men can lift his hands.
76.6: At your rebuke, O God of Jacob, both chariot and horses sleep.
76.7:
You are to be feared, yes, you.
Who can stand before you at the time of your wrath?
76.8:
From heaven you announced judgment.
The earth feared and was quiet
76.9:
when you rose up to judge, O God, Interlude
and to save all the afflicted of the earth.
76.10:
Even the wrath of mankind will bring you praise.
You wear what remains of your wrath like a belt.
76.11:
Make vows to the Lord your God and fulfill them.
Let all who are around him bring tribute to the one who is fearsome.
76.12:
He restrains the spirit of nobles.
He is fearsome against the kings of the earth.

77.1: For the choir director. According to Jeduthun. By Asaph. A psalm.
77.2:
With my voice to God—
with my voice I cried out to God,
and he listened to me.
77.3:
In the day when I was distressed I sought the Lord.
At night my hand was stretched out,
and it never grew tired,
but my soul refused to be comforted.
77.4:
God, I remembered and I groaned. Interlude
I pondered, and my spirit became weak.
77.5:
You propped my eyelids open.
I was troubled but did not speak.
77.6: I thought about the days of long ago, the years long past.
77.7:
During the night I remembered my music.
With my heart I pondered, and my spirit asked,
77.8:
“Will the Lord reject forever?
Will he never again show favor?
77.9:
Has his mercy vanished to the end?
Has what he said failed for all generations?
77.10:
Has God forgotten to be gracious? Interlude
Has he really shut up his compassion in anger?”
77.11:
Then I said, “This is what hurts me:
the change of the right hand of the Most High.”
77.12:
I will remember the deeds of the Lord.
Yes, I will remember your wonderful work from long ago.
77.13:
I will meditate on all your work,
and I will ponder all your deeds.
77.14:
O God, your way is carried out in holiness.
What god is as great as God?
77.15:
You are the God who performs a wonderful deed.
You made known your power among the peoples.
77.16:
With your arm you redeemed your people,
the descendants of Jacob and Joseph. Interlude
77.17:
The waters saw you, O God.
The waters saw you and swirled.
Even the depths were turbulent.
77.18:
The clouds poured down water.
The skies echoed with thunder.
Indeed, your arrows shot back and forth.
77.19:
The sound of your thunder was heard in the tornado.
Lightning lit up the world.
The earth trembled and quaked.
77.20:
Your route led through the sea.
Your trail went through the mighty waters,
but your footprints were not detected.
77.21: You led your people like a flock by the hand of Moses and Aaron.

78.1:
Give ear, O my people, to my instruction.
Turn your ear to the words of my mouth.
78.2:
I will open my mouth to share a lesson.
I will speak about puzzling problems from long ago,
78.3:
things we have heard and known,
things our fathers have told us.
78.4:
We will not hide them from their descendants.
We will tell the next generation the praiseworthy deeds of the Lord,
his power, and the wonders that he has done.
78.5:
He set up testimony for Jacob.
In Israel he established the law.
He commanded our fathers to make it known to their children.
78.6:
Then the next generation would know it,
even the children not yet born.
They would rise up and tell their children.
78.7:
Then they would put their confidence in God,
and they would not forget the deeds of God,
but they would keep his commands.
78.8:
Then they would not be like their fathers,
a stubborn, rebellious generation,
a generation that did not keep their hearts steadfast,
whose spirits were not faithful to God.
78.9:
The tribe of Ephraim, equipped and armed with bows,
    deserted on the day of battle.
78.10: They did not keep God’s covenant, and they refused to walk in his law.
78.11: They forgot his deeds, the wonders he had shown to them.
78.12:
In the presence of their fathers he had performed a wonder,
in the land of Egypt, in the region of Zoan.
78.13:
He split the sea and let them cross through it.
He made the water stand like a wall.
78.14:
He led them with the cloud by day
and all through the night with light from the fire.
78.15:
He split the rocks in the wilderness,
and he let them drink water as plentiful as the deep sea.
78.16:
He brought streams out of the rocky cliff.
He made water flow down like rivers.
78.17:
But they continued to sin against him even more,
    by rebelling against the Most High in the desert.
78.18: They tested God in their hearts by demanding food for their cravings.
78.19:
Then they spoke against God.
They said, “Is God able to set a table in the wilderness?
78.20:
Sure, he struck the rock and water flowed out,
and stream beds overflowed,
but can he really give us bread?
Can he really supply meat for his people?”
78.21:
Then the Lord heard, and he showed his anger.
Fire broke out against Jacob,
and his anger rose against Israel,
78.22:
because they did not believe in God,
and they did not trust in his salvation.
78.23:
Nevertheless, he gave a command to the skies above,
and he opened the doors of the heavens.
78.24:
He rained down manna for them to eat,
and he gave them the grain of heaven.
78.25:
Each of them ate the bread of the mighty ones.
He sent them all the food they could eat.
78.26:
He sent out the east wind from the heavens,
and he led out the south wind by his power.
78.27:
Then he rained meat down on them like dust,
and flying birds like sand on the seashore.
78.28:
He made the birds fall down inside their camp,
    all around their dwellings.
78.29:
Then they ate until they had more than enough,
for he had brought them what they craved.
78.30:
They had not yet turned away from what they craved.
Their food was still in their mouths.
78.31:
Then God’s anger rose up against them.
He killed the strongest among them.
He cut down the best young men of Israel.
78.32:
In spite of all this, they kept sinning,
and they did not believe in his wonders.
78.33:
So he ended their days in frustration
and their years in terror.
78.34:
Whenever he struck them down, they would seek him.
Then they turned and sought God.
78.35:
Then they remembered that God was their Rock,
that God Most High was their Redeemer.
78.36:
But then they would deceive him with their mouths,
and with their tongues they would lie to him.
78.37:
Their hearts were not committed to him,
and they were not faithful to his covenant.
78.38:
Yet he was compassionate.
He atoned for their guilt and did not destroy them.
Many times he restrained his anger,
and he did not stir up his full wrath.
78.39:
He still remembered that they were only flesh,
like a wind that goes by and does not return.
78.40:
How often they rebelled against him in the wilderness!
How often they grieved him in the wasteland!
78.41:
They repeatedly put God to the test.
They provoked the Holy One of Israel.
78.42:
They did not remember the power of his hand—
the day when he redeemed them from the foe,
78.43:
when he displayed his signs in Egypt
and his wonders in the region of Zoan,
78.44:
when he turned their rivers to blood,
so they could not drink from their streams.
78.45:
He sent against them a swarm of flies that bit them.
Then he sent frogs that destroyed them.
78.46:
Then he gave their crops to the grasshopper.
He gave what they worked for to the locust.
78.47:
He killed their grapevines with hail,
and their sycamore fig trees with sleet.
78.48:
Then he turned over their cattle to hail,
and their livestock to lightning bolts.
78.49:
He sent against them his burning anger,
his wrath and indignation and distress
    by sending destroying angels.
78.50:
He prepared a path for his anger.
He did not spare their lives from death,
but he delivered their lives to the plague.
78.51:
Then he struck down all the firstborn in Egypt,
the firstfruit of their virility in the tents of Ham.
78.52:
But he led his people out like sheep.
He led them like a flock through the wilderness.
78.53:
Then he guided them safely, so they were not afraid,
but the sea covered their enemies.
78.54:
Then he brought them to the border of his holy land,
to this mountain which his right hand had taken.
78.55:
He drove out nations before them.
He marked the boundaries of their inheritance,
and he settled the tribes of Israel in their tents.
78.56:
But they tested him.
They rebelled against God Most High,
and they did not keep his testimonies.
78.57:
Yes, they turned aside and were treacherous like their fathers.
They were as undependable as a crooked bow.
78.58:
Then they angered him with their high places,
and they made him jealous with their idols.
78.59:
God heard, and he showed his anger.
He completely rejected Israel.
78.60:
So he abandoned his dwelling in Shiloh,
the tent where he dwelled among people.
78.61:
So he sent the symbol of his strength away into captivity.
He gave his splendor into the hand of the foe.
78.62:
He also handed over his people to the sword,
and he showed his anger against his possession.
78.63:
Fire consumed their best young men,
so their virgins were not praised in wedding songs.
78.64:
Their priests fell by the sword,
and their widows did not weep.
78.65:
Then the Lord awoke like someone who has been sleeping,
like a warrior overcome by wine.
78.66:
Then he drove back his foes.
He gave them everlasting shame.
78.67:
Then he rejected the tent of Joseph,
and he did not choose the tribe of Ephraim.
78.68:
But he chose the tribe of Judah,
Mount Zion, which he loved.
78.69:
Then he built up his sanctuary like the heights,
like the world that he established for all time.
78.70:
Then he chose David his servant
and took him from the sheep pens.
78.71:
He brought him from following the mother sheep
    to shepherd his people Jacob
    and his possession Israel.
78.72:
So he shepherded them with a sincere heart,
and with skillful hands he led them.

79.1:
God, the nations have invaded your possession.
They have profaned your holy temple.
They have reduced Jerusalem to a heap of ruins.
79.2:
They have left the corpses of your servants
    as food for the birds of the sky.
They have given the flesh of your favored ones to the wild animals.
79.3:
They have poured out their blood like water all over Jerusalem,
and there is no one to bury them.
79.4:
We are subjected to contempt by our neighbors,
to mockery and ridicule by those around us.
79.5:
How long, O Lord? Will you stay angry forever?
How long will your jealous anger burn like fire?
79.6:
Pour out your wrath on the nations that do not acknowledge you,
on the kingdoms that do not call on your name,
79.7:
because they have devoured Jacob,
and they have destroyed his pastureland.
79.8:
Do not charge the guilt of our fathers against us.
Hurry, let your compassion come to meet us,
for we are very weak.
79.9:
God, who saves us, help us for the glory of your name.
Deliver us and make atonement for our sins for your name’s sake.
79.10:
Why should the nations say, “Where is their God?”
Before our very eyes, display to the nations
    vengeance for the poured-out blood of your servants.
79.11:
May the groaning of the prisoner come before you.
According to the great strength of your arm
    preserve those doomed to death.
79.12:
Pay back into the laps of our neighbors seven times as much scorn
    as the scorn that they directed at you, Lord.
79.13:
Then we your people, the flock of your pasture, will praise you forever.
From generation to generation we will recount your praise.

80.1: For the choir director. To “Lilies.” A Testimony. By Asaph. A psalm.
80.2:
O Shepherd of Israel, give ear,
you who lead Joseph like a flock.
You who are seated above the cherubim, shine forth.
80.3:
Before Ephraim and Benjamin and Manasseh,
stir up your might.
Come with salvation for us.
80.4:
God, restore us, and make your face shine,
    so we will be saved.
80.5:
Lord God of Armies, how long will your anger smoke
    against the prayer of your people?
80.6:
You make them eat bread with tears,
and you make them drink tears by the quart.
80.7:
You create strife between us and our neighbors,
so our enemies join together in mocking us.
80.8:
God of Armies, restore us, and make your face shine,
    so we will be saved.
80.9:
You brought a vine out from Egypt.
You drove out the nations, and you planted it.
80.10:
You cleared a place for it,
and it took root and filled the land.
80.11:
The mountains were covered by its shade,
the cedars of God with its branches.
80.12:
It sent out its boughs to the Sea,
its shoots as far as the River.
80.13:
Why have you broken down its walls
so that all who pass by pick its fruit?
80.14:
A wild boar from the forest tears it up,
and the wild animals feed on it.
80.15:
God of Armies, return now!
Look down from heaven and see,
and take care of this vine,
80.16:
the shoot that your right hand has planted,
the son that you made strong for yourself.
80.17:
It is burned with fire like garbage.
Because of the rebuke from your face they perish.
80.18:
Let your hand rest on the man at your right hand,
on the son of man whom you have made strong for yourself.
80.19:
Then we will not turn away from you.
Cause us to live, and we will call on your name.
80.20:
Lord God of Armies, restore us, and make your face shine,
    so we will be saved.

81.1: For the choir director. According to gittith. By Asaph.
81.2:
Sing a loud song to God, our strength.
Shout to the God of Jacob!
81.3:
Begin the music, and play the hand drum.
Play the sweet-sounding lyre along with the harp.
81.4:
Sound the ram’s horn at the new moon
and at the full moon for our festival day.
81.5:
Yes, this is an order for Israel,
a regulation from the God of Jacob.
81.6:
God established it as a testimony for Joseph
when he went out against the land of Egypt.
There I heard a language I did not know.
81.7:
The Lord says:
I relieved Israel’s shoulders from the burden.
His hands were set free from carrying buckets.
81.8:
In distress you called and I rescued you.
I answered you from the hiding place of thunder. Interlude
I tested you at the waters of Meribah.
81.9:
Listen, my people, and I will warn you.
If only you would listen to me, Israel!
81.10:
There shall be no foreign god among you!
You shall not bow down to a strange god.
81.11:
I am the Lord your God,
    who brought you up out of the land of Egypt.
Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it.
81.12:
But my people would not listen to my voice,
and Israel was not willing to obey me.
81.13:
So I sent them off in the stubbornness of their hearts.
They walked according to their own plans.
81.14:
If only my people would listen to me,
if only Israel would walk in my ways,
81.15:
I would subdue their enemies quickly.
I would turn my hand against their foes.
81.16:
Those who hate the Lord would cower before him,
and their time of punishment would last forever.
81.17:
But he would feed Israel with the best wheat.
With honey from the rock I would satisfy you.

82.1:
God is standing in the assembly of God.
In the midst of the gods he renders judgment.
82.2:
How long will you judge unjustly Interlude
and show favoritism to the wicked?
82.3:
Judge in favor of the weak and the fatherless.
Acquit the oppressed and the poor.
82.4:
Rescue the weak and the needy.
Deliver them from the hand of the wicked.
82.5:
They do not know. They do not understand.
They walk around in darkness.
All the foundations of the earth are shaken.
82.6:
I myself said, “You are ‘gods,’
and you are all ‘sons of the Most High.’
82.7:
But you will die like men.
You will fall like any other ruler.”
82.8:
Rise up, O God. Judge the earth,
for you will take possession of all the nations.

83.1:
God, do not keep silent.
Do not be deaf. Do not be quiet, God.
83.2:
Look! Your enemies are in an uproar,
and those who hate you have raised their head.
83.3:
Against your people they devise deceptive schemes,
and they plot together against the people you treasure.
83.4:
They say, “Come, let us wipe them out as a nation,
so the name of Israel will not be remembered anymore.”
83.5:
Indeed, with one mind they plot together.
They form an alliance against you—
83.6:
the tents of Edom and the Ishmaelites,
Moab and the Hagrites,
83.7:
Gebal and Ammon and Amalek,
Philistia, with the inhabitants of Tyre.
83.8:
Even Ashshur has joined with them. Interlude
They have become the arm of the sons of Lot.
83.9:
Do to them as you did to Midian,
as you did to Sisera and Jabin at the stream Kishon.
83.10:
They perished at Endor.
They became like manure for the ground.
83.11:
Make their nobles like Oreb and like Zeeb,
all their princes like Zebah and Zalmunna,
83.12: who said, “Let us take possession of God’s pastures for ourselves.”
83.13:
My God, make them like tumbleweed,
like chaff before the wind.
83.14:
As fire burns the forest,
or as a flame sets the mountains on fire,
83.15:
so pursue them with your violent wind,
and terrify them with your storm.
83.16:
Fill their faces with shame
so that they will seek your name, O Lord.
83.17:
May they be ashamed and terrified forever.
May they be disgraced and perish.
83.18:
Let them know that you, whose name is the Lord,
you alone are the Most High over all the earth.

84.1:
For the choir director. According to gittith. By the Sons of Korah.
A psalm.
84.2: How I love your dwelling place, O Lord of Armies.
84.3:
My soul grows weak and even wastes away,
as I long for the courtyards of the Lord.
My heart and my flesh cry out for the living God.
84.4:
Even the sparrow has found a home,
and the swallow has found a nest for herself,
where she may place her young near your altars,
O Lord of Armies, my King and my God.
84.5:
How blessed are those who live in your house. Interlude
They are always praising you.
84.6:
How blessed is everyone whose strength is found in you.
The highways to Jerusalem are in their hearts.
84.7:
As they pass through the Valley of Baca,
    it becomes full of springs.
The autumn rain also covers it with pools.
84.8:
They go from strength to strength.
Each one will appear before God in Zion.
84.9:
O Lord, God of Armies, hear my prayer. Interlude
Give ear, O God of Jacob.
84.10:
Look upon our Shield, O God.
Look with favor on the face of your Anointed One.
84.11:
Yes, one day in your courts is better than a thousand elsewhere.
I would rather wait at the doorway of the house of my God
    than dwell in the tents of the wicked.
84.12:
For the Lord is a sun and shield.
God gives grace and glory.
The Lord does not withhold any good thing
    from those who walk with integrity.
84.13: O Lord of Armies, how blessed is everyone who trusts in you.

85.1:
You showed favor to your land, O Lord.
You restored Jacob.
85.2:
You removed the guilt of your people. Interlude
You covered all their sin.
85.3:
You put away all your wrath.
You turned from your burning anger.
85.4:
Restore us, O God who saves us.
Put an end to your indignation with us.
85.5:
Will you be angry with us forever?
Will you extend your anger through all generations?
85.6:
Will you not turn and revive us,
so that your people may rejoice in you?
85.7:
Show us your mercy, O Lord,
and give us your salvation.
85.8:
I will hear what the true God, the Lord, will say.
He indeed speaks peace to his people, to his favored ones,
but do not let them turn to foolish ways.
85.9:
Surely his salvation is near for those who fear him,
so that glory may dwell in our land.
85.10:
Mercy and truth meet together.
Righteousness and peace kiss each other.
85.11:
Truth springs up from the earth,
and righteousness looks down from heaven.
85.12:
The Lord will indeed give good things,
and our land will yield its harvest.
85.13:
Righteousness walks in front of him.
It prepares the way for his footsteps.

86.1:
Turn your ear, O Lord.
Answer me, for I am poor and needy.
86.2:
Guard my life, for I am favored by you.
You are my God.
Save your servant, who trusts in you.
86.3:
Have mercy on me, O Lord,
for I call to you all day long.
86.4:
Bring joy to the soul of your servant,
for to you, O Lord, I lift up my soul.
86.5:
Indeed, you, Lord, are good and forgiving
and abounding in mercy to all who call to you.
86.6:
Give ear to my prayer, O Lord.
Pay attention to the sound of my cries for mercy.
86.7:
In the day of my distress I will call to you,
    because you will answer me.
86.8:
There is no one like you among the gods, O Lord.
There are no deeds like your deeds.
86.9:
All the nations you have made will come.
They will bow before you, O Lord,
and they will give glory to your name,
86.10:
because you are great and do marvelous deeds.
You alone are God.
86.11:
Teach me your way, O Lord.
I will walk in your truth.
Give me wholehearted commitment to fear your name.
86.12:
I will thank you, O Lord my God, with all my heart,
and I will glorify your name forever.
86.13:
For great is your mercy toward me,
and you have delivered my soul from “the lowest hell.”
86.14:
God, the arrogant rise against me.
A mob of ruthless men seeks my life.
They pay no attention to you.
86.15:
But you, Lord, are a compassionate and gracious God,
slow to anger, abounding in mercy and faithfulness.
86.16:
Turn to me and have mercy on me.
Give your strength to your servant.
Save the son of your maidservant.
86.17:
Give a sign of your goodness for me.
Then those who hate me will see it and be put to shame,
because you, Lord, have helped me and comforted me.

87.1: The city he founded is on the holy mountains.
87.2:
The Lord loves the gates of Zion
    more than all the other dwellings of Jacob. Interlude
87.3: Glorious things are spoken about you, O City of God.
87.4:
I will register Rahab and Babylon among those who know me.
Look! Philistia and Tyre are there, along with Cush!
Of them I say, “This one was born there in Zion.”
87.5:
And about Zion it will be said,
“This one and that one were born in her,
and the Most High himself will establish her.”
87.6:
When he registers the peoples,
the Lord will write: Interlude
“This one was born there.”
87.7:
Then the singers, as they dance, will sing,
“All my springs are in you.”

88.1:
O Lord, the God who saves me, by day I cry out.
At night I cry before you.
88.2:
May my prayer come before you.
Turn your ear to my cry.
88.3:
Indeed, my soul has had its fill of troubles,
and my life has arrived at the grave.
88.4:
I am treated like those who go down to the pit.
I am like someone without strength.
88.5:
I am turned loose with the dead.
I am like the slain who lie in the grave,
like the ones you do not remember anymore,
like those who are cut off from your hand.
88.6:
You have put me in the lowest pit,
in dark places, in the depths.
88.7:
Your wrath presses against me. Interlude
You have battered me with all your breakers.
88.8:
You have distanced my acquaintances from me.
You have made me repulsive to them.
I am shut in and I cannot get out.
88.9:
My eyesight grows dim from affliction.
I call to you, O Lord, every day.
I spread out my hands to you.
88.10:
Is it for the dead that you do a miracle? Interlude
Do the spirits of the dead rise up and praise you?
88.11:
Is your mercy declared in the tomb,
your faithfulness in decay?
88.12:
Is your wonderful work known in the darkness?
Is your righteousness known in the land of forgetfulness?
88.13:
But I cry to you, O Lord,
and in the morning my prayer comes before you.
88.14:
Why, O Lord, do you reject my soul?
Why do you hide your face from me?
88.15:
I have been afflicted
and I have been close to death since my youth.
I have endured your terrors.
I am in despair.
88.16:
Your rage has swept over me.
Your terrors have destroyed me.
88.17:
All day long they surround me like water.
They have battered me completely.
88.18:
You have distanced my loved one and friend from me.
My only friend is darkness.

89.1:
I will sing of the mercies of the Lord forever.
With my mouth I will make your faithfulness known
    through all generations.
89.2:
Yes, I have said, “Your mercy is built to last forever.
In the heavens you establish your faithfulness.”
89.3:
The Lord said,
“I have made a covenant with my chosen one.
I have sworn to David my servant.
89.4:
I will establish your seed forever, Interlude
and I will build your throne through all generations.”
89.5:
The heavens praise your wonders, O Lord,
also your faithfulness in the assembly of the holy ones.
89.6:
For who in the skies can compare with the Lord?
Who is like the Lord among the sons of God?
89.7:
God is revered in the council of the holy ones.
He is to be feared more than all who surround him.
89.8:
O Lord God of Armies, who is like you?
You are mighty, O Lord,
and your faithfulness surrounds you.
89.9:
You rule over the majestic sea.
When its waves rise up, you quiet them.
89.10:
You crushed Rahab like one of the slain.
With your strong arm you scattered your enemies.
89.11:
The heavens are yours, and yours also is the earth.
You founded the world and everything that fills it.
89.12:
You created the north and the south.
Tabor and Hermon shout for joy at your name.
89.13:
Your arm works for you with power.
Your hand is strong. Your right hand is raised high.
89.14:
Righteousness and justice are the foundation of your throne.
Mercy and truth are right in front of you.
89.15:
How blessed are the people who know the joyful cry.
Lord, they walk in the light from your face.
89.16:
In your name they celebrate all day long.
In your righteousness they are lifted up.
89.17:
For you are the beauty of their strength,
and by your favor you exalt our Horn.
89.18:
Indeed, our Shield belongs to the Lord,
our King to the Holy One of Israel.
89.19:
Once you spoke in a vision to your favored ones.
You said:
I have granted help to a warrior.
I have raised up a young man from among the people.
89.20:
I found David my servant.
With my holy oil I have anointed him.
89.21:
He is the one whom my hand will sustain.
Surely my arm will strengthen him.
89.22:
No enemy will subject him to tribute.
No violent man will oppress him.
89.23:
I will crush his foes before him
and strike down those who hate him.
89.24:
My faithfulness and mercy will be with him,
and through my name his horn will be exalted.
89.25:
I will set his hand over the sea,
his right hand over the rivers.
89.26:
He will call out to me, “You are my Father,
my God and the Rock that saves me.”
89.27:
I will also make him the Firstborn,
the highest of the kings of the earth.
89.28:
I will keep my mercy for him forever,
and my covenant with him will stand firm.
89.29:
I will establish his seed forever.
His throne will endure like the days of the heavens.
89.30:
If his sons forsake my law,
and they do not walk according to my judgments,
89.31: if they violate my statutes and do not keep my commands,
89.32: I will punish their rebellion with the rod, their guilt with whipping.
89.33:
But I will not break off my mercy from him.
I will not let my truth become false.
89.34:
I will not violate my covenant.
I will not alter what comes out of my lips.
89.35:
Once and for all, I have sworn by my holiness—
surely I will not lie to David—
89.36:
that his seed will continue forever,
and his throne will endure before me like the sun.
89.37:
It will be established forever like the moon. Interlude
This witness in the sky is faithful.
89.38:
But you have rejected, you have cast off,
you have been very angry with your anointed one,
89.39:
and you have renounced the covenant with your servant,
and you have thrown his crown on the ground.
89.40:
You have broken down all his walls
and reduced his fortresses to rubble.
89.41:
All who pass by on the road have plundered him.
He is despised by his neighbors.
89.42:
You have raised up the right hand of his foes.
You have made all his enemies happy.
89.43:
Indeed, you have deflected the edge of his sword,
and you have not let him stand up in battle.
89.44:
You have put an end to his majesty,
and you have hurled his throne to the ground.
89.45:
You have cut short the days of his youth. Interlude
You have clothed him with shame.
89.46:
How long, O Lord? Will you hide yourself forever?
Will your wrath burn like fire?
89.47:
Remember me! What is my life!
For you have created such futility for all the children of Adam!
89.48:
Can anyone live and not see death, Interlude
or save his life from the power of the grave?
89.49:
Where are your former mercies, O Lord,
which you swore to David in your faithfulness?
89.50:
Remember, Lord, the scorn your servants have endured.
(I carry on my heart all the many peoples!)
89.51:
Remember the scorn
    with which your enemies have been scornful, O Lord,
    with which they have scorned the steps of your Anointed One.
89.52:
Blessed be the Lord forever!
Amen and Amen.

90.1: Lord, you have been our dwelling place throughout all generations.
90.2:
Before the mountains were born,
before you gave birth to the earth and the world,
from eternity to eternity you are God.
90.3:
You grind people to dust,
and you say, “Return, children of Adam.”
90.4:
For a thousand years in your sight are like a day,
like yesterday that has gone by,
or like a watch in the night.
90.5:
You sweep them away like a flood.
They are like sleep in the morning,
like grass which changes quickly.
90.6:
In the morning it sprouts and grows.
By evening it is cut down, and it withers.
90.7:
Surely, we are consumed by your anger,
and by your wrath we are terrified.
90.8:
You have laid out our guilty deeds in front of you.
Our hidden sins are revealed in the light of your face.
90.9:
For all our days pass away under your fury.
We finish our years like a sigh.
90.10:
The days of our lives add up to seventy years,
or eighty years if we are strong.
Yet the best of them are trouble and sorrow,
for they disappear quickly, and we fly away.
90.11:
Who can understand the power of your anger?
But your fury is consistent with the fear that is owed to you.
90.12:
Teach us to number our days in such a way
    that we bring a heart of wisdom.
90.13:
Turn, O Lord! How long!
Change your mind toward your servants.
90.14:
Satisfy us in the morning with your mercy,
so that we may sing for joy and be glad all our days.
90.15:
Make us glad for as many days as you have afflicted us,
for as many years as we have seen trouble.
90.16:
Let your deeds be seen by your servants
and your majesty by their children.
90.17:
May the kindness of the Lord our God rest upon us.
Establish the work of our hands for us.
Yes, establish the work of our hands.

91.1:
One who lives in the shelter of the Most High
    will stay in the shadow of the Almighty.
91.2:
I will say to the Lord,
“My refuge and my fortress, my God in whom I trust.”
91.3:
Surely he will rescue you from the fowler’s trap,
from the destructive plague.
91.4:
With his feathers he will cover you,
and under his wings you will find refuge.
His truth will be your shield and armor.
91.5:
You will not fear the terror of night,
nor the arrow that flies by day,
91.6:
nor the plague that prowls in the darkness,
nor the pestilence that destroys at noon.
91.7:
A thousand may fall at your side,
ten thousand at your right hand,
but it will not come near you.
91.8:
You will only observe it with your eyes.
You will see the punishment of the wicked.
91.9:
Yes, you, Lord, are my refuge!
If you make the Most High your shelter,
91.10:
evil will not overtake you.
Disaster will not come near your tent.
91.11:
Yes, he will give a command to his angels concerning you,
    to guard you in all your ways.
91.12:
They will lift you up in their hands,
so that you will not strike your foot against a stone.
91.13:
You will tread on the lion and the cobra.
You will trample the young lion and the serpent.
91.14:
The Lord says,
Because he clings to me, I will rescue him.
I will protect him, because he acknowledges my name.
91.15:
He will call on me, and I will answer him.
I will be with him in distress.
I will deliver him and I will honor him.
91.16:
With long life I will satisfy him,
and I will let him see my salvation.

92.1:
It is good to give thanks to the Lord,
to make music to your name, O Most High,
92.2:
to proclaim your mercy in the morning
and your faithfulness every night,
92.3:
with a ten-stringed instrument and with a harp,
with a melody on a lyre.
92.4:
Yes, you make me glad by your work, O Lord.
I sing loudly at the works of your hands.
92.5:
How great are your works, O Lord.
Your thoughts are very deep!
92.6:
The senseless man does not know,
and the fool does not understand this—
92.7:
when the wicked spring up like weeds,
and all evildoers bloom like flowers,
they will be destroyed forever.
92.8: But you are exalted forever, O Lord.
92.9:
Without a doubt your enemies, O Lord,
without a doubt your enemies will perish.
All evildoers will be scattered.
92.10:
But you have raised my horn like that of a wild ox.
I am drenched with fresh oil.
92.11:
My eyes have looked in triumph over my adversaries.
When evildoers rise against me, my ears hear their defeat.
92.12:
The righteous will shoot up like a palm tree.
They will grow tall like a cedar in Lebanon.
92.13:
Planted in the house of the Lord,
they will shoot up in the courtyards of our God.
92.14:
They will still produce fruit in old age.
They will stay fresh and green.
92.15:
Yes, they can proclaim, “The Lord is upright.
He is my Rock, and he does no wrong.”

93.1:
The Lord reigns. He is clothed in majesty.
The Lord is clothed—he wears strength like a belt.
Yes, the world stands firm. It will not be moved.
93.2:
Your throne was established long ago.
You are from eternity.
93.3:
The waves have lifted up, O Lord,
the waves have lifted up their voice.
The waves roar loudly.
93.4:
Mightier than the thundering of the great waters,
mightier than the breakers of the sea,
the Lord on high is mighty.
93.5:
Your testimonies stand very firm.
Holiness beautifies your house for endless days, O Lord.

94.1:
O Lord, God of vengeance,
God of vengeance, shine forth.
94.2:
Rise up, O Judge of the earth.
Repay the proud with what they deserve.
94.3:
How long will the wicked, O Lord,
how long will the wicked celebrate?
94.4:
They gush. They speak arrogantly.
All the evildoers brag about themselves.
94.5:
They crush your people, O Lord.
They oppress the people that belong to you.
94.6:
They kill the widow and the alien.
They murder the fatherless.
94.7:
Then they say, “The Lord does not see.
The God of Jacob does not understand.”
94.8:
Understand, you brutes among the people.
You fools, when will you become wise?
94.9:
The one who planted the ear—will he not hear?
The one who formed the eye—will he not observe?
94.10:
The one who disciplines nations—will he not rebuke them?
He is the one who teaches mankind knowledge.
94.11:
The Lord knows the thoughts of mankind.
He knows that they are just vapor.
94.12:
How blessed is the person whom you discipline, O Lord,
whom you teach from your law.
94.13:
You grant him rest in days of trouble,
until a pit is dug for the wicked.
94.14:
For the Lord will not desert his people,
and he will never forsake those who are his own.
94.15:
Then judgment will again be based on righteousness,
and all the upright in heart will pursue it.
94.16:
Who will rise up for me against the wicked?
Who will take a stand for me against evildoers?
94.17:
Unless the Lord had been my helper,
my soul would soon have dwelt in silence.
94.18:
When I said, “My foot has slipped,”
your mercy, Lord, upheld me.
94.19:
When my worries within me were many,
your comfort brought joy to my soul.
94.20:
Can a destructive throne be allied with you,
one that creates injustice by its decrees?
94.21:
They band together against the life of the righteous,
and they condemn innocent blood.
94.22:
But the Lord has become my fortress,
and my God is the rock where I take refuge.
94.23:
Then he will repay them for their iniquity,
and he will destroy them for their wickedness.
The Lord our God will destroy them.

95.1:
Come, let us sing joyfully to the Lord.
Let us give a loud shout to the Rock who saves us.
95.2:
Let us approach his presence with thanksgiving.
With music we will shout to him.
95.3:
For the Lord is the great God
and the great King above all gods.
95.4:
He holds the unexplored places of the earth in his hand,
and the peaks of the mountains belong to him.
95.5:
The sea belongs to him, for he made it,
and his hands formed the dry land.
95.6:
Come, let us bow down. Let us revere him.
Let us kneel before the Lord our Maker,
95.7:
for he is our God,
and we are the people of his pasture
and the flock in his hand.
Today, if you hear his voice,
95.8:
do not harden your hearts as they did at Meribah,
as they did that day at Massah in the wilderness,
95.9:
where your fathers challenged me
and tested me though they had seen what I had done.
95.10:
For forty years I was disgusted with that generation,
and I said, “They are a people who have hearts that stray.
They do not acknowledge my ways.”
95.11:
So I swore in my anger,
“They shall never enter my resting place.”

96.1:
Sing to the Lord a new song.
Sing to the Lord, all the earth.
96.2:
Sing to the Lord. Praise his name.
Proclaim the good news of his salvation from day to day.
96.3:
Tell about his glory among the nations,
about his marvelous deeds among all peoples.
96.4:
For great is the Lord and worthy of great praise.
He is to be feared above all gods.
96.5:
For all the gods of the peoples are “nothings,”
but the Lord made the heavens.
96.6:
Splendor and majesty are before him.
Power and beauty are in his sanctuary.
96.7:
Ascribe to the Lord, families of peoples,
Ascribe to the Lord glory and power.
96.8:
Ascribe to the Lord the glory due his name.
Bring a gift and come into his courtyards.
96.9:
Bow down to the Lord in the splendor of his holiness.
Look away from his face, all the earth.
96.10:
Say among the nations, “The Lord reigns.”
The world is firmly established.
It will not be moved.
He will judge the peoples with fairness.
96.11:
Let the heavens rejoice.
Let the earth celebrate.
Let the sea roar,
and all that fills it.
96.12:
Let the fields be overjoyed,
and everything that is in them.
Then all the trees of the forest will sing for joy
96.13:
before the Lord, for he comes,
    for he comes to judge the earth.
He will judge the world in righteousness
and the peoples in his faithfulness.

97.1:
The Lord reigns. Let the earth celebrate.
Let the many islands and coastlands rejoice.
97.2:
Clouds and deep darkness surround him.
Righteousness and justice are the foundation of his throne.
97.3:
Fire goes out in front of him.
It burns up his foes all around him.
97.4:
His lightning lights up the world.
The earth sees and writhes in pain.
97.5:
The mountains melt like wax
    in the presence of the Lord,
    in the presence of the Lord of all the earth.
97.6:
The heavens proclaim his righteousness,
and all the peoples see his glory.
97.7:
All who serve idols are put to shame,
those who boast in “nothings.”
Bow to him, all you gods!
97.8:
Zion hears and rejoices,
and the daughters of Judah celebrate
    because of your judgments, O Lord.
97.9:
For you, O Lord, are the Most High over all the earth.
You are raised up far above all gods.
97.10:
Let those who love the Lord hate evil.
He guards the lives of his favored ones.
He delivers them from the hand of the wicked.
97.11:
Light rises for the righteous
and joy for the upright in heart.
97.12:
Rejoice in the Lord, you righteous,
and give thanks as you remember his holiness.

98.1:
Sing to the Lord a new song,
for he has done marvelous things.
His right hand and his holy arm have worked salvation for him.
98.2:
The Lord has made his salvation known.
He has revealed his righteousness to the eyes of the nations.
98.3:
He has remembered his mercy and his faithfulness
    to the house of Israel.
All the ends of the earth have seen the salvation of our God.
98.4:
Shout for joy to the Lord, all the earth.
Break out in joyful song! Make music!
98.5:
Make music to the Lord with the lyre,
with the lyre and the sound of music.
98.6:
With trumpets and the sound of the ram’s horn
    shout for joy before the King, the Lord.
98.7:
Let the sea roar, and everything that fills it,
the world, and all who live in it.
98.8:
Let the rivers clap their hands.
Let the mountains sing for joy together before the Lord,
98.9:
for he comes to judge the earth.
He will judge the world in righteousness
and the peoples with fairness.

99.1:
The Lord reigns. Let the peoples tremble.
He is seated above the cherubim. Let the earth quake.
99.2: The Lord is great in Zion. He is exalted over all the peoples.
99.3:
Let them praise your name, great and awesome.
He is holy!
99.4:
The King is mighty. He loves justice.
You, Lord, have established fairness.
In Jacob you carried out justice and righteousness.
99.5:
Exalt the Lord our God and bow down before his footstool.
He is holy!
99.6:
Moses and Aaron were among his priests.
Samuel was among those who call on his name.
They called on the Lord, and he answered them.
99.7:
From within the pillar of cloud he spoke to them.
They kept his testimonies and the order that he gave them.
99.8:
O Lord our God, you answered them.
For them you were a God who removes sin,
but you repaid them for their deeds.
99.9:
Exalt the Lord our God,
and bow down before his holy mountain,
because the Lord our God is holy.

100.1: Shout to the Lord with joy, all the earth.
100.2:
Serve the Lord with gladness.
Come before him with joyful songs.
100.3:
Know that the Lord is God.
He made us, and we are his.
We are his people, the sheep of his pasture.
100.4:
Enter his gates with thanksgiving,
his courtyards with praise.
Give thanks to him and bless his name.
100.5:
For the Lord is good. His mercy endures forever.
His faithfulness continues through all generations.

101.1:
I will sing about your mercy and justice.
To you, O Lord, I will make music.
101.2:
I will act wisely, following the way that is honest.
When will you come to me?
Within my palace I will conduct myself with integrity.
101.3:
I will not tolerate an evil cause in my sight.
I hate unfaithfulness and apostasy.
It will not stick to me.
101.4:
A perverted heart shall be kept far from me.
I will not acknowledge evil.
101.5:
I will silence anyone who slanders his neighbor in secret.
I cannot tolerate anyone who has arrogant eyes and a proud heart.
101.6:
My eyes will watch for the faithful in the land,
so that they can be seated with me.
Those who walk in the way of integrity will serve as my ministers.
101.7:
Anyone who practices deceit will not sit inside my palace.
Anyone who is a liar will not stand in my sight.
101.8:
Every morning I will silence all the wicked in the land,
